G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Springfield, Massachusetts, which is located in Hampden County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Prejudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (.proposition: In Massachusetts, to prove negligence, the Plaintiff must establish the following elements: (1) the Defendant owed a legal duty to the Plaintiff, (2) the Defendant breached that duty, (3) the breach was the proximate cause of the Plaintiff’s harm, and (4) the Plaintiff sustained damages as a result.
*Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements the plaintiffs must prove in *this* negligence case, but it articulates them in a shorter three-part formulation (duty/breach, actual loss, and causation) and cites the Restatement rather than stating a canonical Massachusetts four-element test including “proximate cause” and “damages as a result.” The court’s focus is on causation and the failure of proof, not on formally defining all elements of negligence in Massachusetts. Thus, this case does not clearly establish the specific four-element proposition quoted.
*Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

*Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty of reasonable care to secure the ladder he stored in a shared parking area, as a reasonable person would foresee the risk of harm posed by an unsecured ladder in a windy environment.
*Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence discussing abandonment of common‑law entrant classifications (invitee/licensee/trespasser) and the general move toward a unitary standard of reasonable care by occupiers. It does not address ladders, shared parking areas, wind, or any specific duty to secure stored objects, nor does it discuss foreseeability in that concrete context. Thus, this citation does not provide direct authority for the particularized proposition about a duty to secure a ladder in a windy environment.
*Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

See *Cormier v. Lynn, 479 Mass. 35, 37 (.raw_text: See *Cormier v. Lynn, 479 Mass. 35, 37 (2018)* ("A defendant breaches a duty of care when their actions foreseeably cause harm to others").
See *Cormier v. Lynn, 479 Mass. 35, 37 (.proposition: A foreseeable risk materialized when the ladder fell due to strong wind, a condition entirely foreseeable given the manner in which it was stored.
See *Cormier v. Lynn, 479 Mass. 35, 37 (.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a foreseeable risk materializing when a ladder fell due to wind, invoking a general negligence concept that a defendant breaches a duty when foreseeable harm occurs. Cormier v. Lynn is about sovereign immunity under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act, focusing on whether public defendants ‘originally caused’ a situation under § 10(j), not on general foreseeability of harm from physical conditions like a ladder in the wind. The opinion does not discuss ladders, wind, or apply a foreseeability analysis analogous to the proposition, so it does not support that specific statement.
See *Cormier v. Lynn, 479 Mass. 35, 37 (.relevant_excerpt: "Thus, the issue that we must decide is not whether the school was negligent for failing to act reasonably to prevent the bullying that led to Matthew's injuries; the complaint alleges that it was, and for purposes of this appeal, we accept that allegation as true. Rather, the issue on appeal is whether, under the act, the public defendants may be held liable for that negligence. We conclude that the act protects them from liability for such negligence."

*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.raw_text: *Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 901 (1987)* (recognizing property damage as a compensable harm under negligence law).
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered a compensable injury under Massachusetts law in the form of property damage and financial loss.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals exclusively with duty and foreseeability in a premises-liability negligence claim (whether the restaurant had a duty to protect patrons from an out-of-control vehicle). It does not discuss the concept of compensable injury, nor does it address whether property damage or financial loss constitutes a cognizable harm under Massachusetts negligence law. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that property damage and financial loss are compensable injuries under Massachusetts law.
*Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus.relevant_excerpt: “The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

*Schlittler v. Dold, 233 Mass. 199, 200-.proposition: Massachusetts common law principles also impose liability for harm caused by an object under one’s control when that harm arises out of a failure to secure the object, as Defendant’s actions demonstrate in this case.
*Schlittler v. Dold, 233 Mass. 199, 200-.case_name: Massachusetts General Hospital v. Inhabitants of Belmont
*Schlittler v. Dold, 233 Mass. 199, 200-.support_reasoning: The opinion is a tax and constitutional law case about the validity and application of a Massachusetts statute governing tax exemptions for certain charitable institutions, specifically insane asylums. It does not address tort liability, duties to secure objects, or any common-law principles regarding harm caused by objects under one’s control. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition concerning Massachusetts common-law liability for failure to secure an object.
*Schlittler v. Dold, 233 Mass. 199, 200-.relevant_excerpt: These are two petitions under Part I, § 77 of the general tax act, St. 1909, c. 490, appealing from the refusal of the assessors of the town of Belmont to abate taxes alleged to have been assessed illegally for the years 1915 and 1916 respectively upon real estate of the petitioner devoted to the care of the insane under a department known as the McLean Asylum and located in that town.

See *Leclerc v. Cote, 406 Mass. 501, 503.proposition: Defendant’s inaction violated community safety standards and constitutes negligence for which he is liable.
See *Leclerc v. Cote, 406 Mass. 501, 503.support_reasoning: The opinion in Leclerc v. Cote is a criminal case about the admissibility of prior bad acts evidence to prove identity in an assault with intent to rape prosecution. It does not discuss negligence, community safety standards, or liability based on inaction. The holding concerns evidentiary rules for prior crimes, so citing it for a negligence/inaction proposition misstates its substance and context.
See *Leclerc v. Cote, 406 Mass. 501, 503.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that evidence that the defendant committed similar but unconnected crimes against different victims is inadmissible… We have held that evidence of prior bad acts is not admissible to prove identity unless there is a special mark or distinctiveness in the way the acts were committed… There was no ‘mark’ or unique feature common to the three assaults… that would justify admitting evidence of the prior acts to prove that the defendant was the person who committed the assault on the victim in this case.”
